<Summary source="https://www.trendforce.com/news/2026/01/26/news-chinese-ai-models-reportedly-hit-15-global-share-in-nov-2025-fueled-by-deepseek-open-source-push/">
# Summary of Article: Chinese AI Models Reportedly Hit ~15% Global Share in Nov. 2025

## Key Facts and Statistics:

- **Chinese AI models reached approximately 15% of global market share in November 2025**, according to a Nikkei report cited by TrendForce
- This represents a sharp increase from **around 1% market share a year earlier** (November 2024)
- **Approximately 40% of AI models developed by Chinese companies are used for advanced tasks**, such as programming and design

## Named Sources and Context:

- **Source**: Nikkei report, cited by TrendForce News
- The growth is attributed to China's open-source model strategy, particularly following DeepSeek's initial impact "a year ago" (referring to DeepSeek R1's January 2025 release)

## Key Players Mentioned:

- **DeepSeek**: Released R1 model in January 2025, which "stunned the world by achieving high performance at low cost"
- **Alibaba Group's Qwen (Tongyi Qianwen)**: Described as central to China's AI ecosystem alongside DeepSeek, with frequent upgrades

## Market Context:

- U.S. firms' flagship models are noted as predominantly closed-source with pay-per-use pricing models
- China's AI ecosystem is centered on open-source approaches
- The generative AI development landscape has been largely driven by U.S. companies since ChatGPT's release in November 2022

**Note**: The article references "global market share" but does not specify the exact methodology or whether this aligns with OpenRouter's specific market share calculations.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/04/cnbcs-the-china-connection-newsletter-for-chinese-businesses-its-not-about-which-ai-is-the-smartest.html">
# Summary of CNBC Article: "For Chinese businesses, it's not about which AI is the smartest"

**Date:** February 04, 2026  
**Author:** Evelyn Cheng

## Key Facts and Statistics:

### Pricing Comparisons:
- OpenAI's gpt-oss open-weight model and DeepSeek: **30 cents per 1 million tokens** (cheapest)
- Google's Gemini 3 Pro: **$4.50 per 1 million tokens**
- Anthropic's Claude Opus 4.5: **$10 per 1 million tokens**
(Source: Artificial Analysis benchmarking)

### OpenRouter Rankings (as of article date):
- **Week referenced:** Last week (late January/early February 2026)
- **Top 4 by usage:**
  1. Anthropic (U.S.)
  2. Google (U.S.)
  3. **DeepSeek (China) - ranked 3rd**
  4. **Moonshot AI's Kimi K 2.5 (China) - ranked 4th** (just days after launch)

### Business Impact:
- AI productivity gains: 10 people can complete work that previously required 20-30 people (according to Wenhao Zhang, CEO of Doodod Technology)
- Doodod Technology roughly doubled its client base to "well over 100 customers" in the last year

### Moonshot AI Metrics:
- Revenue from outside China has **surpassed domestic market revenue** since K 2.5 model release
- New overseas users **quadrupled** after latest model launch
- Valuation surged by **at least $500 million in just a few weeks** (reported by CNBC last month)

## Key Opinions from Named Sources:

**Sun Xin, Vice President of Research at Gartner:**
- Chinese companies no longer prioritize "who is the smartest" when selecting AI solutions
- Instead focus on: reliability, control over hallucinations, and integration capacity

**Tong (from Movitech):**
- Since second half of 2025, company has used AI agents for manufacturing process improvement and SOE compliance
- Had to lower product prices due to economic pressures, but AI boosted internal efficiency
- Without AI gains, business would be in "far weaker position"

**Liqian Ren, Director of Modern Alpha at WisdomTree:**
- "As long as the private sector of China continues to have the leeway to make money, China's innovation can be kept up with the U.S., then people are going to be interested in Chinese equities"

**Damien Ma, Director of Carnegie China:**
- We are living in an "à la carte interest-based world" rather than a values-based one
- Doubts there will be a new "golden age" of UK-China and US-China economic relations

## Context on Chinese AI Usage:
- Chinese businesses use AI more for specific situations vs. U.S. companies using it more for coding
- Locally run open-source models preferred because they don't require uploading information to third-party cloud servers
- U.S. models (Google, Anthropic's Claude) not officially available in China due to Beijing's firewall and national security bans
- However, U.S. models are being used by local developers despite restrictions
- Chinese models gaining overseas users, especially those trying Open Claw AI agent
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.scmp.com/tech/tech-trends/article/3335602/chinas-open-source-models-make-30-global-ai-usage-led-qwen-and-deepseek">
# Summary of Article: "Chinese open-source models account for 30% of global AI use: report"

**Source:** South China Morning Post  
**Date:** December 08, 2025

## Key Facts and Statistics:

1. **Chinese model market share trajectory (from Open Router data):**
   - Late 2024: Started at 1.2% global share
   - Reached nearly 30% "over a few months" in 2025
   - 2025 year-to-date average: 13% of weekly token volume

2. **Comparative benchmarks:**
   - Chinese open-source LLMs averaged 13% weekly token volume in 2025
   - AI models from "the rest of the world" (excluding US and China, presumably) averaged 13.7% in 2025
   - Growth accelerated in the second half of 2025

3. **Data source:** 
   - Open Router empirical study analyzing 100 trillion tokens

## Key Opinions:

**From the report (reliable, named source - Open Router):**
- "China has emerged as a major force, not only through domestic consumption but also by producing globally competitive models"
- The report characterizes China as producing "globally competitive models," making it "a close peer of the US in AI development"

## Note:
The article provides specific historical data points from Open Router through December 2025, showing significant growth in Chinese model adoption on the platform during 2025.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.scmp.com/news/article/3342951/chinas-ai-arms-race-sees-sector-brace-major-flagship-model-launch-week">
# Summary of "China's AI arms race sees sector brace for major flagship model launch week"

**Source:** South China Morning Post  
**Date:** February 09, 2026

## Key Facts and Developments:

### Alibaba's Qwen-3.5 Release
- An Alibaba Cloud model-development team member issued pull requests on Hugging Face and GitHub for the next-generation Qwen family of models on Sunday (preceding the article date)
- **Qwen-3.5** is the centerpiece, arriving almost a year after Qwen-3's release
- **Qwen-3's performance in 2025:** Became the most popular open-model family globally over the course of 2025, attributed to strong performance, permissive license, and wide range of use cases

### Qwen-3.5 Technical Specifications:
- Will include two models: one at 9 billion parameters and another at 35 billion parameters
- Features native multimodal support for the first time (can understand and process text, images, and audio)
- Uses the company's next-generation architecture, first previewed in September in an experimental model called Qwen 3-Next

### Other Developments:
- A "stealth" model has emerged (no further details provided in the excerpt)
- Zhipu's GLM-5 is also mentioned as an upcoming advancement
- These releases aim to spur domestic competition following releases by US competitors

### Context:
- Alibaba Cloud is the AI and cloud computing unit of Alibaba Group Holding (owner of South China Morning Post)
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.cnn.com/2026/02/10/tech/china-us-ai-race-challenges-intl-hnk-dst">
# Summary of CNN Article: "China AI industry looks unstoppable, but is it?"

**Date:** February 11, 2026  
**Author:** John Liu

## Key Facts and Statistics:

- **Performance gap assessment:** At a Beijing meeting in January 2026, Justin Lin (Alibaba's Qwen technical lead) estimated chances of a Chinese AI firm overtaking US frontrunners in 3-5 years at "below 20 percent," calling even 20% "very optimistic"

- **Chinese model market share growth:** According to a late 2025 study by OpenRouter, Chinese open models' global usage skyrocketed from 1.2% in late 2024 to nearly 30% in 2025

- **Recent IPO activity:** In January 2026, Chinese AI unicorns Z.ai (Zhipu) and MiniMax went public in Hong Kong, raising $560 million and $620 million respectively, with surging share prices

- **Chip access constraints:** US export controls bar Chinese companies from obtaining cutting-edge chips like Nvidia's Blackwell and Rubin series. Trump approved export of Nvidia's H200 chips (two generations behind Rubin), but China has not yet officially greenlit their import

## Named Source Opinions:

**Justin Lin (Alibaba Qwen technical lead):**
- Assessed probability of Chinese AI overtaking US at below 20% in 3-5 years
- Stated: "OpenAI, Anthropic and other American companies are putting massive compute into next-gen research, whereas we are relatively stretched thin"

**Tang Jie (Z.ai/Zhipu founder):**
- Warned the performance gap between Chinese and US models "may be widening"
- Acknowledged "challenges and gaps we still face"

**Lian Jye Su (Omdia chief analyst):**
- Noted "open sourcing has to a certain extent become an industry consensus in China"
- Explained open-source strategy reduces costs and lessens geopolitical risk exposure

**Jenny Xiao (Leonis Capital partner):**
- Stated Chinese companies have "no other choice" but open-source: "Chinese people, like consumers, as well as enterprises, do not pay for software"
- Explained Chinese AI companies are "burning a lot of cash" and going public is "the easiest way" to address this

**Paul Triolo (Albright Stonebridge consultant):**
- On domestic chip alternatives: "Their problem is they can't get the volume" due to US restrictions hampering Chinese chipmakers' ability to scale output

**Deepika Giri (IDC head of AI research):**
- Noted AI is "becoming more ubiquitous" in China despite model limitations
- Stated "industrialization of AI is progressing extremely rapidly"

**Yao Shunyu (former OpenAI researcher, now Tencent chief AI scientist):**
- Said China has demonstrated ability to "very quickly catch up or replicate" Western technological developments and sometimes "go on to do it even better"
- Identified cultural shortage of risk-takers as bigger challenge for China pulling ahead of US

## Additional Context:

- DeepSeek reportedly set to unveil new model with enhanced coding capabilities later in February 2026
- Meta announced acquisition of Manus (AI agent firm founded in China, relocated to Singapore) in December, though deal faces Beijing regulatory review
- Reuters reported (citing anonymous sources) that DeepSeek, Alibaba, ByteDance, and Tencent received conditional approvals from Beijing to purchase H200 chips
- Beijing unveiled action plan to deepen AI use in manufacturing as part of national industrial upgrade strategy
- Chinese leader Xi Jinping highlighted AI models "racing ahead" in televised new year address
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://venturebeat.com/ai/a-weekend-vibe-code-hack-by-andrej-karpathy-quietly-sketches-the-missing">
# Summary of Article: "A weekend 'vibe code' hack by Andrej Karpathy quietly sketches the missing layer of enterprise AI orchestration"

**Source:** VentureBeat  
**Date:** November 26, 2025

## Key Facts and Developments:

### The LLM Council Project
- Andrej Karpathy (former Tesla AI director and OpenAI founding member) created a weekend project called "LLM Council" - a system where multiple AI models debate and synthesize answers
- The project was described as "vibe code" - software written quickly, largely by AI assistants, intended for fun rather than production use
- Karpathy explicitly stated he would not support the project: "Code is ephemeral now and libraries are over"

### Technical Architecture
- **Backend:** Built on FastAPI (Python framework)
- **Frontend:** Standard React application built with Vite
- **Data storage:** Simple JSON files on local disk
- **Key infrastructure component:** OpenRouter - an API aggregator that normalizes differences between model providers

### Models Used in Default Configuration:
- OpenAI's GPT-5.1
- Google's Gemini 3.0 Pro
- Anthropic's Claude Sonnet 4.5
- xAI's Grok 4
- Chairman LLM: Google's Gemini 3

### How It Works:
1. User query is sent to multiple frontier models in parallel
2. Each model evaluates anonymized responses from other models (peer review)
3. A "chairman LLM" synthesizes all responses into a final answer

### Observations from Karpathy:
- Models were "surprisingly willing to select another LLM's response as superior to their own"
- When reading book chapters, models consistently praised GPT-5.1 as most insightful while rating Claude lowest
- Karpathy's personal assessment diverged: he found GPT-5.1 "too wordy" and preferred Gemini's "condensed and processed" output

### Enterprise Implications Discussed:
The article notes that while the core logic is simple, production deployment would require:
- Authentication and user role management
- PII redaction and compliance mechanisms
- Audit logging
- Circuit breakers, fallback strategies, and retry logic
- Governance layer for managing data sent to external providers

### Market Context:
- The article positions this as demonstrating the "commoditization of the model layer"
- Commercial vendors (LangChain, AWS Bedrock, AI gateway startups) sell the "hardening" infrastructure around such core logic
- Models can be swapped by editing a single configuration line (COUNCIL_MODELS list)

**Note:** The article appears to be cut off at the end, so the final section on "When AI models judge AI" is incomplete.
</Summary>

**From Grade 9 On, Visit Sichuan Science and Technology Museum’s 'Super AI' Exhibition Hall**
From February 19 to 23, 2026 (the third to seventh days of the Lunar New Year), the Sichuan Science and Technology Museum will host the 'Tian Si Xun You, Ji Jun Na Fu' Spring Festival Garden Party, featuring an interactive exploration journey inspired by the ancient Chinese star constellation 'Tian Si'. Visitors can complete challenges at four themed exhibition areas—'Qi Ji', 'Tian Si', 'Long Ma', and 'Shen Jun'—to collect limited-edition 'Jun Fu' lucky paper, with only 1,000 pieces available daily. The museum’s newly opened fourth-floor 'Super AI' artificial intelligence exhibition hall, developed over more than a year, will also debut during the festival. The exhibition offers immersive, interactive, and visual experiences, including an 'AI Growth Timeline Corridor' showcasing key milestones from Alan Turing’s ideas to China’s 'Loongson' breakthroughs and the current global large-model wave. Interactive zones include a 'Data' area where users feel AI's 'touch' via pressure-sensitive screens, a 'My Home' transparent glass room displaying real server racks, and a 'My Brain' section transforming complex neural networks like RNN and CNN into tangible, touchable installations. Visitors can write digits on a screen to see AI recognition in action. In the 'AI Applications' area, guests can experience AI avatars, smart traditional Chinese medicine diagnosis (for reference only), and the 'AI Director Workshop', where they create stories and scenes that generate videos displayed on a 'Story Wall' for public interaction. The 'My City' collaborative experience area simulates Chengdu’s real map with eight stations, allowing participants to act as urban managers optimizing traffic flow and handling emergencies using AI-powered autonomous vehicles. The museum is closed on February 16–18 (New Year’s Eve to the second day of the Lunar New Year) and will reopen on February 19, with regular hours from 9:00 to 17:00 (last entry at 16:30). The museum will also be open on February 14–15 and February 26–28.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 15, 2026 02:36 PM
Source:[k.sina.com.cn](https://k.sina.com.cn/article_1496814565_593793e502001y53o.html)

**Chinese New Year AI Showdown: The Battle for Control of Software Production in the Age of AI**
The Chinese New Year 2026 'AI model release season' has intensified competition among major AI companies, with firms like Alibaba (Qwen-3.5, Qoder), ByteDance (Douyin's Dabao 2.0), DeepSeek (V4), MiniMax (M2.5), and Zhipu (GLM-5) launching new models focused on AI programming and agent capabilities. These models emphasize reasoning efficiency, long-context understanding, low-cost inference, and multimodal integration. Key technical advancements include MoE (Mixture of Experts) architectures, FP8 precision, and optimized inference frameworks, reducing per-call costs from 'yuan' to 'fen'. The competition reflects a strategic shift from broad conversational AI to engineering-grade AI systems capable of end-to-end software development. This shift is driven by the 'Day 2 Problem'—AI excels at generating code (Day 1) but struggles with sustainable, maintainable software engineering (Day 2). Industry leaders like OpenAI and Google are advancing specialized models (e.g., Gemini 3 Deep Think, GPT-5.3-Codex-Spark) to address this. Market demand is surging: IDC forecasts China’s generative AI software market to reach $3.54 billion by 2025, with an additional $15 billion in latent demand unlocked by low-cost AI development. A positive feedback loop exists between models, products, users, and data. Large firms like Alibaba leverage ecosystem integration (e.g., Qwen in Alipay, Taobao) and open-source strategies (Apache 2.0) to build developer communities. Smaller players like MiniMax and Zhipu focus on vertical specialization—MiniMax M2.5 targets high-throughput, efficient agent tasks with only 10B active parameters; Zhipu GLM-5 uses a 744B total / 40B active MoE design for optimal efficiency. The market is dividing: big tech dominates B2B with 90% projected market share in three years, while niche players thrive in specialized, high-knowledge domains. Despite progress, challenges remain: 'Agent Washing' (overhyping basic bots as agents), hallucinations, data silos, and the '80-point trap'—where demos look good but real-world deployment fails. Success requires long-horizon capabilities: planning consistency, state management, error recovery, and cost optimization. The emergence of 'Agentic Engineering'—using AI agents to manage full software lifecycles—marks a paradigm shift. By 2027, AI tools could cover 80% of software development tasks, freeing developers for architecture and strategy. 2026 is seen as the turning point from 'explosion' to 'delivery'—from talking to acting, from generating to orchestrating. Experts stress that AI Agent adoption hinges on solving reliability, cost control, and ethical compliance. As Beijing Academy of Social Sciences researcher Wang Peng notes, AI agents represent a qualitative leap from 'cognition' to 'action,' reshaping production and interaction models.

**China's Open-Source AI Models Surge to 15% Global Market Share, Sparking Japan's Push for Domestic Alternatives**
Chinese-developed open-source generative AI models have risen to approximately 15% of the global market share by November 2025, up from just 1% a year earlier, according to data compiled by the U.S. AI tool platform OpenRouter and venture capital firm a16z, which measure AI model input/output volumes. Between November 2024 and November 2025, China’s open-source AI market share averaged 13%, with some weeks reaching as high as 30%. Key models driving this growth include DeepSeek’s R1, launched in January 2025, praised for achieving high performance at low cost, and Alibaba’s Qwen (Qianwen), which is frequently updated. About 40% of Chinese AI models are used in advanced applications such as programming and design. Performance evaluations by Japan’s NIKKEI Digital Governance ranked DeepSeek’s model 9th out of 92 models in December 2025, first among open-source models, surpassing open-source models from Google and OpenAI. In Japan, 6 out of the top 10 AI models developed by Japanese companies, including those by ABEJA, are based on DeepSeek and Qwen. Japan’s National Institute of Informatics (NII) also uses Qwen in its domestic AI project, LLM-jp. However, reliance on foreign open-source models poses risks, as changes in licensing terms can abruptly restrict development and usage. In response, Japan is initiating efforts to develop domestic open-source models, with the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry including support policies in its 2026 budget, aiming for a 1 trillion yen investment over five years, led by private firms like SoftBank. To be adopted in real-world business environments, Japan’s AI must achieve performance competitive with leading U.S. and Chinese models, requiring advanced multimodal capabilities (handling text, images, and voice) and overcoming increasingly high technical barriers.

**WIRED Magazine: 2026 Will Be the Year of Alibaba's Qwen**
On December 29, 2025, WIRED, a leading global technology magazine, published a headline article titled 'Goodbye, GPT-5. Hello, Qwen.' The article states that despite GPT-5 failing to generate market excitement, Alibaba's Qwen—open-source and highly flexible for deployment—will dominate in 2026. According to WIRED, the true measure of an AI model's value lies not only in its intelligence but in its ability to enable the development of other applications. In this regard, Chinese open-source models like Qwen are clearly on the rise. Although models from OpenAI (GPT-5), Google (Gemini 3), and Anthropic (Claude) typically score higher, Qwen and other Chinese models such as DeepSeek remain in the top tier and are gaining increasing popularity due to their strong performance and developer-friendly flexibility. Data from Hugging Face, the world's largest AI open-source community, shows that Chinese open-source models surpassed American models in downloads by July 2025, with Qwen ranking first. Additionally, OpenRouter data on third-party API usage indicates that Qwen surged to fourth place globally in model call volume in 2025.

Publish date: December 29, 2025 01:32 PM
Source:[东方财富网](https://finance.eastmoney.com/a/202512293604634071.html)

**Geopolitical Tensions Cannot Hinder China's Rise in Low-Cost AI Models**
According to a report released in early December by OpenRouter and Andreessen Horowitz, China's share of AI workloads globally rose from 1.2% at the end of 2024 to over 30% by early August 2025. This surge followed the release of DeepSeek's R1 model in mid-January 2025, which demonstrated performance comparable to top U.S. models, signaling China's growing maturity in generative AI. Unlike closed models such as OpenAI’s GPT or Google’s Gemini, DeepSeek-R1 and other Chinese large language models (LLMs) offer free downloads and open weights, enabling customization. Wang Wen from Renmin University told AFP that 'the world is increasingly choosing Chinese models due to their low cost—sometimes even free—and strong performance.' An anonymous U.S. entrepreneur reported saving $400,000 annually by using Alibaba’s Qwen (Tongyi Qianwen) model for business applications, noting that while top-tier tech still comes from OpenAI, Anthropic, or Google, most use cases do not require it. Qwen is adopted by organizations including Perplexity, Nvidia, and Stanford University. Other popular Chinese models include GLM by Zhipu AI, MiniMax, and Moonshot’s Kimi K2, which achieved breakthroughs in AI agent capabilities—a domain previously considered a Chinese weakness. Despite the U.S. government’s July roadmap supporting open-weight and open-source AI, major American firms have shown little interest: Meta has shelved its Llama models in favor of closed AI, and OpenAI only recently launched two GPT-oss open-weight models after six years of closed development. Mistral in France remains the only major Western firm committed to open-source, yet it lags far behind DeepSeek and Qwen in OpenRouter’s popularity rankings. The entrepreneur noted that China actively encourages open-source models, which are more frequent and feature-rich than European counterparts. Mark Barton of Omniux Consulting acknowledged customer concerns over using Chinese models, especially amid Trump administration policies, stating, 'We don’t want to be in a bind if a company is sanctioned.' However, Paul Triolo of DGA-Albright Stonebridge Group argued that data security is not a core issue, as companies can run these models on-premise without connecting to China. Stanford researchers recently concluded that open models allow deeper structural scrutiny, enhancing trust. High Fei of BOK Health agreed, stating that 'openness and sharing are the best way to build trust.' The Stanford study concluded that widespread adoption of Chinese models could 'redefine technology access pathways and dependencies,' while 'reshaping AI governance, security, and competitive dynamics.'

Publish date: December 22, 2025 08:30 AM
Source:[RFI](https://www.rfi.fr/tw/%E4%B8%AD%E5%9C%8B/20251222-%E5%9C%B0%E7%B7%A3%E6%94%BF%E6%B2%BB%E7%B7%8A%E5%BC%B5-%E4%B8%AD%E5%9C%8B%E5%BB%89%E5%83%B9ai%E6%A8%A1%E5%9E%8B%E4%BB%8D%E8%84%AB%E7%A9%8E%E8%80%8C%E5%87%BA)

**Geopolitical Tensions Cannot Hinder China's Low-Cost AI Models from Gaining Global Ground**
According to a report released in early December by OpenRouter and Andreessen Horowitz, China's share of global AI model usage in AI tasks rose from 1.2% at the end of 2024 to over 30% by early August 2025. This surge followed the January 2025 release of DeepSeek-R1, a Chinese startup model whose performance rivals top U.S. models, signaling China's growing maturity in generative AI. Unlike OpenAI's GPT or Google's Gemini, DeepSeek-R1 and many other Chinese large language models (LLMs) offer free downloads and open weights (allowing partial modification). Wang Wen from Renmin University of China told AFP that 'the world is increasingly choosing Chinese models due to their low cost—sometimes even free—and strong performance.' An anonymous U.S. entrepreneur reported saving $400,000 annually by using Alibaba’s Qwen (Tongyi Qianwen) model. He noted, 'If you need cutting-edge technology, you return to OpenAI, Anthropic, or Google. But for most applications, it’s not necessary.' Qwen is used by organizations including Perplexity, Nvidia, and Stanford University. Other popular Chinese models include GLM (Zhipu AI), MiniMax, and Moonshot’s Kimi K2, which achieved breakthroughs in AI agent capabilities—a domain previously considered a Chinese weakness. Despite the U.S. Trump administration’s July 2025 roadmap supporting open-weight or open-source AI, major U.S. firms have shown little interest. Meta has shelved its Llama models in favor of closed-source AI, and OpenAI only released two open-weight models, GPT-oss, in August 2025—after six years of no such offerings. Mistral in France remains the only major Western company committed to open-source, yet it lags far behind DeepSeek and Qwen in OpenRouter’s popularity survey. The entrepreneur observed that while the open-source business model remains unclear, Beijing actively encourages it, noting that European competitors release products less frequently and with fewer specifications, making them less attractive. Mark Barton, head of Omniux Consulting, said he is considering Qwen but acknowledged some clients may feel uneasy about using Chinese models, even for specific tasks. He added, 'Given the Trump administration’s stance toward Chinese tech companies... we don’t want to put all our chips on one model, as sanctions could leave us in a dilemma.' However, Paul Triolo, partner at DGA-Albright Stonebridge Group, argued that data security is not a 'core issue,' as 'companies can run these models on their own devices without connecting to China.' Stanford University researchers, in a study released earlier this week, concluded that 'the open nature of these models allows for deeper structural scrutiny.' High Fei, technology lead at BOK Health, agreed: 'Transparency and sharing through open source are the best ways to build trust.' The Stanford researchers concluded that the widespread adoption of Chinese models could 'redefine pathways to technological access and interdependence,' while 'reshaping AI governance, security, and competitive dynamics.'

**Chinese Open-Source AI Models Reach 13% Global Usage Share**
Chinese open-source AI models accounted for 13% of global AI usage in 2025, according to the 'State of AI Report' by OpenRouter and Andreessen Horowitz (a16z), which analyzed real-world usage of 100 trillion tokens from November 2024 to November 2025. At the end of 2024, Chinese open-source models held only a 1.2% market share. Their growth surged after the January release of DeepSeek's R1 and the July launch of Moonshot AI's Kimi K2, with their share peaking at 30% during specific weeks. While closed models still dominate 70% of usage, the report noted that Chinese models have shown a 'notable upward trend' since the start of the year. The rise is attributed to cost-effective performance and rapid update cycles, with Alibaba's Qwen and DeepSeek's models releasing new versions frequently to meet diverse demands like coding, reasoning, and conversation. OpenRouter stated, 'China's rapid update strategy has substantially reshaped the open-source AI landscape,' and emphasized that it has 'advanced global competition across the LLM environment.'

Publish date: December 09, 2025 07:36 AM

**Share of Chinese Open-Source Language Models on Global AI Market Rises to 30%**
The share of Chinese open-source large language models on the global AI market has risen to 30% this year, according to data from OpenRouter and analysts at Andreessen Horowitz cited by the South China Morning Post. In late 2024, these models accounted for only 1.2% of global token processing, but by the end of 2025, their share has grown nearly to 30%. Chinese-language AI model requests remain the second most frequent globally after English. Leading Chinese models include Alibaba's Qwen series, DeepSeek V3, and Moonshot AI's Kimi K2. The remaining 70% of token operations are handled by closed-source Western models, such as OpenAI’s GPT series. In early 2025, Chinese open-source models reached a 13% share of weekly token usage, with growth accelerating in the second half of the year. Non-Chinese models account for 13.7% of weekly usage by geographic origin. The report confirms that Chinese large language models are increasingly used not only domestically but also internationally.

**Chinese open-source models account for 30% of global AI use: report**
According to an empirical study by OpenRouter analyzing 100 trillion tokens, Chinese open-source large language models (LLMs) increased their global share from 1.2% in late 2024 to nearly 30% within a few months in 2025. Tokens, which are units of data processed by AI models during training and inference, enable tasks such as prediction, generation, and reasoning. In 2025, Chinese open-source LLMs averaged 13% of weekly token volume, with growth accelerating in the second half of the year, bringing their share close to the 13.7% average of AI models from the rest of the world. The report stated, 'China has emerged as a major force, not only through domestic consumption but also by producing globally competitive models.'

**China's open-source models make up 30% of global AI usage, led by Qwen and DeepSeek**
China's open-source artificial intelligence models accounted for nearly 30% of global AI usage in 2025, according to a report by OpenRouter and Andreessen Horowitz. This marks a significant increase from 1.2% in late 2024. The surge was driven by Chinese-developed models such as Alibaba's Qwen family, DeepSeek's V3, and Moonshot AI's Kimi K2. Chinese-language prompts ranked second in token volume globally, behind English. Proprietary Western models, including OpenAI's GPT-4o and GPT-5, still held a dominant 70% global share. The report analyzed 100 trillion tokens and found that Chinese open-source LLMs averaged 13% of weekly token volume in 2025, approaching the 13.7% share of models from the rest of the world. The report highlighted that China has become a close peer to the United States in AI model development despite U.S. restrictions on advanced GPUs. It attributed the rise to competitive quality, rapid iteration, and dense release cycles by companies like Alibaba Cloud and DeepSeek. According to the report, 'China has emerged as a major force, not only through domestic consumption but also by producing globally competitive models.'
